verses.text: O God, you are my God, earnestly I seek you; my soul thirsts for you, my body longs for you, in a dry and weary land where there is no water.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 63
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 63 This beautiful psalm expresses quiet confidence in God’s ability to protect the psalmist.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 63:title
rsbNotes.text: 63:title The setting of the psalm is the desert of Judah.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 63:1
rsbNotes.text:
63:1 thirsts. Cf. Ps. 42.

my flesh. The Book of Psalms permits no false spiritualization. The whole person yearns for God, not merely a non-physical aspect of the person.

verses.text: I have seen you in the sanctuary and beheld your power and your glory.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 63:2
rsbNotes.text: 63:2 in the sanctuary. The psalmist remembers the place of God’s appointment, and the vision of God’s “power” and “glory” entrusted to him there.

verses.text: Because your love is better than life, my lips will glorify you.
I will praise you as long as I live, and in your name I will lift up my hands.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 63:3
rsbNotes.text: 63:3 your steadfast love. That is, the unchanging love God shows toward those joined to Him by His covenant.

verses.text: My soul will be satisfied as with the richest of foods; with singing lips my mouth will praise you.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 63:5
rsbNotes.text: 63:5 will be satisfied. Only in praise to God, in intimate communion with Him, will the psalmist feel spiritually content.

verses.text: On my bed I remember you; I think of you through the watches of the night.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 63:6
rsbNotes.text: 63:6 watches of the night. The psalmist has confidence in the Lord when he is most vulnerable to fear and attack.

verses.text: Because you are my help, I sing in the shadow of your wings.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 63:7
rsbNotes.text: 63:7 your wings. God may be compared to a mother bird who protects her young, but see second note on 61:4.

verses.text: My soul clings to you; your right hand upholds me.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 63:8
rsbNotes.text: 63:8 My soul clings to you. Though far removed from the sanctuary, the place where he has experienced God’s presence, the psalmist still enjoys intimate communion with Him. Clinging to the Lord means finding in Him one’s only hope (Deut. 10:20; 11:22).

verses.text: They who seek my life will be destroyed; they will go down to the depths of the earth.
They will be given over to the sword and become food for jackals.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 63:9
rsbNotes.text: 63:9 seek to destroy my life. This verse is the first indication of distress or danger in the poem of the psalmist’s distress.

verses.text: But the king will rejoice in God; all who swear by God's name will praise him, while the mouths of liars will be silenced.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 63:11
rsbNotes.text: 63:11 who swear by him shall exult. God’s justice wins out. Those who love God will continue to praise Him, while the wicked will be stifled.
